Deaf or dead, disabled or disappeared, this pain of being passed around as nothing more than a piece of land haunts their entire existence. Politics. Change. Fear and chaos. Trauma. Disability. Hou Hsiao-hsien's A City of Sadness just captures the passage of time, using it to outline an entire history. Like Zhang Yimou's To Live and Edward Yang's A Brighter Summer Day, there's something perfectly reflexive about these early 90s simple retellings of mid-century China and Taiwan.
A City of Sadness covers tumultuous history, namely the White Terror and commencement of martial law in Taiwan.… more

Less intimate perhaps, but more wide raging than A Time to Live and a Time to Die. It is more obvious symbolic, the historical period, the brothers, the way art and language function inside it, but it also makes a lot out of Hou’s emphasis on gestures and reactions to the big events, historical and emotional, around the characters. It makes sense it won the Golden Lion that year despite Hou not quite being an acknowledged master at the time, as its importance feel as apparent as its greatness.

Wen-heung is Groucho, Wen-ching is Harpo, Wen-leung is Chico, and the brother who disappeared during the war is Zeppo. Hope this is helpful to any western viewers confused by some of the nuances of Taiwanese history.

"In life I was separated from the fatherland. In death, I return." 

Hou Hsiao-Hsien encapsulates decades of despair into one film that, rather than narrowing in on the grand moments, chronicles familial experiences following Japan's period of colonial rule in Taiwan. It's a masterful exploration of the connection between the personal and the historical, and a powerful portrait of an oppressive government increasingly marked by corruption. One of the most emotionally complex historical tragedies ever made.

Ellipses viewed through entryways and exits that lead to nothing, nowhere.
War breeds loss, and it lingers in every corner of every room in every home bound by borders that harbor nations; the malignant residual cost of nationalist conflicts. Evil spreads pernicious seeds along its pitted path of total domination. These dark, deceitful seeds will grow to appear prosperous, at least, that’s the line they claim. Yet this persecutory command leaves families and country one and the same to fall in pieces like pinkish-white petals of dying blossoms.
Not the beginning, nor the end…
